Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge reasonably concluded the applicant failed to meet the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 551 days within the 4-year period
Absences considered a life pattern, not temporary
Court_Ruling: Citizenship judge's decision was reasonable and adequately explained
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada, maintained primary connections abroad
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to meet physical presence and residential connection requirements
Assessment_Factor: Koo factors applied to assess connection to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court appeal of citizenship judge’s decision
Application_Basis: Residency requirement: 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over 4 years and genuine residential connection
Governing_Rule: Koo factors for assessing residency intent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of residential connection to Canada
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged denial of citizenship due to failure to meet residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Judge reviewed travel records and personal/business connections
Residency_Compliance: Not met – excessive absences and lack of meaningful connection to Canada
Evidence_Assessment: Judge found absences were habitual, not temporary
Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not demonstrate required physical presence or residential intent; absences formed a life pattern
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
